cards.back: A complex number V = Vm∠φ that represents the amplitude (Vm) and phase (φ) of a sinusoid Vm·cos(ωt + φ). It does not contain the frequency.

cards.front: How do you extract a phasor from v(t) = Vm·cos(ωt + φ)?
cards.back: The phasor is V = Vm∠φ. Simply take the amplitude and phase from the cosine function. Drop the cos(ωt + ...) part.

cards.front: How do you convert a sine signal to phasor form?
cards.back: First convert to cosine: sin(ωt + φ) = cos(ωt + φ - 90°). Then extract the phasor: Vm∠(φ - 90°).

cards.front: How do you handle a negative amplitude like -A·cos(ωt + φ)?
cards.back: Add 180° to the phase: -A·cos(ωt + φ) = A·cos(ωt + φ - 180°). The phasor is A∠(φ - 180°).

cards.front: What does differentiation correspond to in the phasor domain?
cards.back: Multiplication by jω. So dv/dt ↔ jωV. This scales amplitude by ω and adds 90° to the phase.

cards.front: What does integration correspond to in the phasor domain?
cards.back: Division by jω. So ∫v(t)dt ↔ V/(jω). This divides amplitude by ω and subtracts 90° from the phase.

cards.front: How do you convert a phasor V = Vm∠φ back to the time domain?
cards.back: v(t) = Re{Ve^(jωt)} = Vm·cos(ωt + φ). Multiply the phasor by e^(jωt) and take the real part.
A plot of one or more phasors as arrows on the complex plane. Length = amplitude, angle from positive real axis = phase. Used to visualise relative phase differences between signals.

cards.front: Why does the phasor method only work for signals of the same frequency?
cards.back: Because the time factor e^(jωt) is factored out and assumed identical for all signals. If frequencies differ, the relative phases change with time and phasor addition breaks down.

cards.front: Who introduced the phasor method for solving AC circuits?
cards.back: Charles Proteus Steinmetz (1865-1923), a German-Austrian mathematician and electrical engineer.
